title: Chunk fetcher returns empty chunks when first page has no images
description: App.fetchChunk currently requests exactly one AIC page per chunk. If that page contains only records without image_id, we mark the chunk ready with no tiles and the board shows a blank gap until the user pans far enough to trigger a different page. We need to cycle through multiple pages (with a deterministic stride) until we gather enough artworks, or give up after some capped attempts.

Tiles only start fetching when fully visible
description: Artwork tiles render with loading="lazy" so the browser waits until the node is inside the viewport before issuing network requests. Because our grid already virtualizes with an off-screen buffer, this causes obvious pop-in when panning—the DOM node exists but the IMG doesn’t start loading until it is basically visible. We should eagerly request images as soon as the buffered tile mounts so they are already decoded by the time the viewport reaches them.

title: Prevent masonry reshuffle when expanding canvas
Entire chunk stays blank when its page has zero imageable works
description: fetchArtworksPage filters out entries with no image_id, but we never backfill if a given API page contains zero usable works. When that happens the chunk is marked ready with an empty artworks array, recomputePlacements drops it entirely, and the viewport shows a permanent empty rectangle. We need to deterministically skip empty pages (and optionally sample a few extra) so every chunk eventually resolves to at least one tile.

title: Tiles only start fetching when fully visible
description: Artwork tiles render with loading="lazy", so the browser postpones network fetches until the image is essentially inside the viewport. Because our grid already virtualizes with a padded buffer, this causes obvious pop-in when panning—the DOM node exists but the img starts loading too late. We should eagerly request images as soon as the buffered tile mounts so they are ready by the time the viewport reaches them.

title: Board clamp stops chunk requests after long pan
description: ArtworkGrid clamps the board translation to a fixed 400x400-cell canvas. After dragging far enough, the clamp prevents the world bounds from advancing, so App never requests new chunk coordinates and the viewport goes blank with no network activity. We need to allow the viewport to keep advancing (e.g., by re-centering the board when we cross the virtual edges).
